awd_titl_txt: Chemistry without Cofactors: Discovering How a Protein Environment Facilitates Important Reactions with Oxygen
awd_abstract_narration:
Metabolism of food by cells occurs over a long and elaborate series of steps inside our cells, which is, in essence, similar to the chemical reaction known as combustion, in which the carbon compounds combine with oxygen gas (O2), to yield carbon dioxide, water, and large amounts of energy. The "flint", hidden inside proteins, consists of small metal-containing or vitamin-like compounds called cofactors, which bind the O2 molecule and begin to break apart its chemical bonds. The partially dismantled oxygen molecule is then ready to combine with carbon-containing molecules from food, releasing vast amounts of energy. In this way, cofactors allow nature to harness and control the power of atmospheric O2. The main objective of this project is to investigate a surprising variation on this process. Recently discovered proteins catalyze reactions between carbon-containing molecules and O2 without the help of cofactors. This project examines how these proteins effectively generate "fire without flint" or energy without cofactors. This project also examines an important potential biotechnological application of these proteins. A cofactor-free, protein-based catalyst can be easily grown in bacterial cultures without the need for the expensive added ingredients or elaborate biochemical pathways needed for assembling cofactors into proteins. These biocatalysts moreover offer clean, byproduct-free alternatives to existing chemical methods for carrying out similar processes. This project specifically examines how cofactor-free proteins can efficiently convert the abundant, renewable plant polymer known as lignin into starting materials for the production of bioplastics. This project will train K through 8 teachers and help develop a course about teaching teachers on issues of sustainability and science education. Research training and education of graduate and undergraduate students will also be supported by this project.

O2 is an ideal oxidant because of its thermodynamic power, abundance, and the benign nature of its by-products. However, O2 possesses unpaired electron spins, making reactions between O2 and organic molecules impractically slow unless a catalyst is present. Biological catalysis of reactions with O2 generally depends on cofactors. The requirement for cofactors to mediate O2 biocatalysis is generally considered absolute. However, bacterial enzymes that catalyze diverse reactions between O2 and organic species in the complete absence of cofactors have recently been discovered. The main objective for this project, which focuses on a large family of cofactor-independent enzymes, is to determine how the protein environment alone activates O2 and steers the activated species toward the formation of specific products. This objective integrates experiment with several levels of theory. This project is supported jointly by the Molecular Biophysics Cluster of the Molecular and Cellular Biosciences Division in the Directorate for Biological Sciences and Chemistry for Life Processes Program of the Chemistry Division in the Directorate of Mathematical and Physical Sciences.

por.por_cntn:
Carbon is the quintessential ingredient of life on earth. From its gaseous forms (carbon dioxide) in the atmosphere, carbon is drawn down by photosynthetic plants and microbes that fix it into their own biological structures Deep in the oceans, biological carbon has accumulated and been transformed over eons into petroleum reserves, which are recovered and used alternately for fuels and for producing materials, including plastics. The greatest socioeconomic challenges today ? climate change, depleted fossil fuels, agricultural sufficient hinge on stewardship and biotechnological leveraging of the global biological carbon cycle. Our work examined a family of bacterial enzymes that accelerate reactions between carbon sources and atmospheric oxygen in a remarkably efficient way. Specifically, unlike almost every known enzyme reaction involving oxygen gas, these enzymes do not require the use of cofactors: small and expensive metal- or non-metal vitamin-like compounds. Consequently, we thought these might provide an inexpensive means of facilitating reactions between oxygen and carbon sources like lignin, a web-like carbon structure that makes plant structures rigid and water-tight. Lignin is an abundant carbon source that currently is treated as a waste product that is mostly burned. Our work showed how enzymes from this cofactor independent family work and demonstrated in principle how they could be used to catalyze reactions important for reclaiming lignin as a valuable product.

In the process of exploring these applications, we initiated a collaboration with Dr. Gregg Beckham at the National Renewable Energy Lab (NREL) that led to two unexpected discoveries. First, we developed new enzyme-catalyzed reactions that use oxygen to break apart the pieces or subunits of lignin. Second, we noted that these same subunits closely resemble those for another carbon material famous for its rigid, water-proof properties: polyester plastic. We employed the approaches and partnerships developed in the preceding phase of the project toward pioneering new biological reactions for bringing waste plastic back into productive use. Importantly, the goal is not simply to turn waste lignin or plastic into carbon dioxide using microbial metabolism. Rather, we aim to convert these waste products into molecules that can be reused, in principle forever (upcycling for the circular economy).

All together, this work resulted in 7 primary research papers and 2 review articles; 2 Ph.D./1 M.S./6 B.S. students graduated and 1 postdoc trained; two US/UK student exchanges; a DOE-funded 10-month student internship at NREL, and a new network of international collaborations focused on the biological capture and remodeling of carbon sources, using oxygen gas. This includes the ?BOTTLE.org? consortium, established at NREL with the PI as a founding member. Finally, our group experienced an unexpectedly high level of public engagement as a result of this work, with numerous requests for interviews from radio, print, internet, and television media. We developed new, hands-on K-5 educational outreach focused on the interplay of the atmosphere and earth, which we were able to implement on either side of the school shutdowns necessitated by the pandemic.
